Summary: I am a 1X founder, hard-core engineer, non status quo business woman, deal-maker, immigrant and the child of the best parents in the universe who happen to be a journalist and an engineer.   I founded Massive Bio after a family situation in cancer because I am obsessed with enabling access to clinical trials to cancer patients around the globe regardless of their location and/or financial stability. I am also obsessed with 'making things work' regardless of how difficult it is or even if I am the only person in the universe that believes in it. Lastly, I am obsessed with delighting our pharmaceutical and CRO customers as I understand the value of gaining and retaining customers.  Prior to Massive Bio, I was at the founding team of EY's Private Equity Value Creation where I helped private equity companies in investment decisions in healthcare and how to maximize their return from their portfolio companies in their investment life-cycle. I have been a part of hundreds of deals. I spent 10 years in management consulting firms.  In my career, I have always combined strategy, operations and transactions but laser-focused on a specific industry. Revenue generation, profitability and capital efficiency are my objective functions in building businesses. I enable hyper growth but a smart one, not a dumb one where 95% of the digital health companies target.    Though I am hugely in love to Massive Bio and be with it until I die, I don't see myself slowing down and I will continue to found new companies. I just don't want to build a company and I want to build an industry.   Outside healthcare, I am interested in energy and transportation industries. I am deeply inquisitive about the intersection of mathematics and technology.   Prior to business, I finished half a dozen engineering degrees (2 BS+2 MS+PhD), mostly from University of Michigan, and I have even done a quick stint at majoring Math.  Nothing in life has presented to me and thus I always have to work very hard and show extreme perseverance to achieve my dreams.  I am an amateur spinner and a dancer, I don't climb mountains, I don't surf and I don't even have a dog, not even one!

Summary: We live in a world where 95% of startup founders who set out to raise capital, fail for one reason or another.  I created Fulcrum Venture Accelerator to help fix this problem. After raising multiple rounds of financing at Kindara, I realized that instead of the disorganized approach that most founders take, I could take a systematic approach to raising capital.  I created a 5 step process for raising seed capital - Tilling, Planting, Watering, Harvesting, Closing. By defining the steps and following my own recipe, I not only knew exactly what to do at every step of my raise, I was also able to raise bigger and bigger rounds as Kindara grew.  After Prima-Temp acquired Kindara, I started helping friends raise seed rounds using the fundraising process I developed. I was excited to see that the process could be taught and applied successfully by entrepreneurs in different industries.  Running out of money is the #1 reason startups fail. I‚Äôve seen many good companies fail because the founder wasn‚Äôt able to raise seed funding. Many founders go about the fundraising process in a disorganized and scattered way, or worse they don‚Äôt follow a process at all, and they end up wasting a huge amount of time and come up empty handed.  Of course this isn‚Äôt their fault, because nobody has been teaching founders a proven process to raise seed funding, and walking them through the steps until now.  In 2020 I founded Fulcrum, a fundraising accelerator for mission-driven entrepreneurs. Every quarter we look for the best companies with a positive social mission, and put them through a rigorous process of fundraising development to help them execute on their raise. We spend time making sure founders understand the process at a deep level, and execute a successful fundraise so they can close their round and get on with building their company.   I like to remind founders that they can delegate marketing, product, finance, customer support, operations, manufacturing, and design, but they can‚Äôt delegate fundraising. For this reason becoming excellent at fundraising can massively turbo-charge what a given founder is able to accomplish and the difference they are able to make.  We help our founders be among the top 1% of entrepreneurs when it comes to raising money. To date more than $20M in pre-seed and seed capital has been raised using our process. We look for high-caliber founders who are building something impactful and who are currently raising (or about to be raising) seed capital. Learn more and apply at www.fulcrumventureaccelerator.com
Title: Founder of Fulcrum Venture Accelerator: The Fundraising Accelerator for Mission Driven Entrepreneurs (Applications now open for our Feb cohort). Founder of Kindara (Acquired)

Summary: I choose to work with people who make a difference.  I work as both 'business therapist' and 'kingmaker' for ideas, humans, and organizations. I came honestly by this trade of ideation, intellectual property extraction, and thought leadership development: I was born to a developmental pediatrician and a poetry therapist, both of them bicameral-thinking healers of minds, bodies, and spirits. I also have a PhD in creativity (actually, classical composition), studying, practicing, and teaching ancient and modern techniques of ideation, publication, and dissemination.  First it was a book and a speech. Clients who brought a script or an idea to me asked for wordsmithing and design. Sensing a sea change coming in the world of publishing, In 2005, I founded independent book publisher, Blooming Twig, releasing hundreds of books, winning awards, and standing for 'books that matter'.  I relished ten years of chalk dust and ideas, teaching writing, leadership, service learning, language, and music to bright-eyed Millennials as a professor at three New York universities. I wrote an award-winning book of my own, and was the ghostwriter of 50 titles. Then, I stood center stage on a red, carpeted dot, giving a TED Talk about the importance of risk-taking and the creative life.  The words I featured as the title of that talk, 'We Are Alive,' mouthed by my father's parched and broken lips around the tubes down his throat, changed my life forever. And now those three words have become anthemic on social media, leading to more than 100 million views, hundreds of thousands of followers, and a humbling task ahead:  How will I become an amplifier for amplifiers? How can I do good by doing well, and do well by doing good? Much to my joy, I have become a town crier, a social media savant, and a serial entrepreneur. I am committed to working with individuals and businesses who have the courage to step out and be unabashedly unique.

Summary: I watched my close friend, Eric, be taken by cancer in six months' time.  My vibrant and energetic friend suffered from mouth sores that made eating painful, resulting in rapid weight loss and, ultimately, succumbing to his cancer.  His family and friends searched, but did not find, safe and clinically appropriate symptom management support.  I thought that if this could happen to Eric and his family, it must be happening to many people. I left my career on Wall Street and spent two years researching the scientific literature regarding the symptom and side effects experienced by cancer patients and interviewing cancer patients, caregivers, and the medical professionals who treat them so that I could create a solution to address these unmet needs in a scientific and clinically appropriate manner.  I found that nutritional strategies are effective in managing the symptoms of cancer and cancer treatment and represent an effective lever to improve outcomes and lower cost of care.  The result of this research is Ina ¬Æ, a virtual 'Intelligent Nutrition Assistant' chatbot who provides personalized nutritional strategies for symptom management 24/7 'on demand' via SMS text on a smartphone.  Licensed by healthcare enterprises and provided free of charge to cancer patients and caregivers, Ina ¬Æ, provides the support Eric and his family were searching for.
Title: CEO & Founder at Savor Health | Personalized Nutritional Strategies as Interventions for Symptom Management Support for People With Cancer & Other Chronic Diseases

So, I know what it really takes and it wasn't easy, but I was determined as a Black woman navigating to become a leader.  Based on my success, I committed myself to develop and help individuals in achieving what they never thought was professionally possible, especially women and women of color at work. What these experiences prepared and positioned me for was to become an expert in women‚Äôs leadership and the advancement of women and women of color in the workplace. Most recently to create my media channel called, ‚ÄúAdvancing Women in the Workplace with FrancineParham and Co.‚Äù that I host to ensure the right conversations and insights of other leaders and experts are heard who are also committed to this work like me.    So, I hope you can take away from all of my work and experiences of over two decades that I'm super focused on what women and women of color want and need to advance successfully in their careers. I‚Äôve lived and practiced what I talk about and know to be the realities and the truths at work. And I‚Äôm continuing to share what I learned and know to help other women and especially women of color professionally advance as I did. I know that nothing is achieved alone. Summary: I am a partner at a litigation law firm in NYC and the CEO of Karta Legal, a 2021 National Law Journal Legal Technology Trailblazer and a legal operations consultancy. I am a graduate from the University of Pennsylvania Law School and Georgetown University's School of Foreign Service, a Legal Project Manager and a Lean Six Sigma Black Belt. Throughout my career, as a partner in private practice and in my current role, I have represented governmental and quasi-governmental agencies, as well as publicly-held Fortune 100 companies. I am honored to have been recognized as a Trailblazer by the New York Law Journal in 2019 for being an 'agent of change, thought leader and innovator.'  For the past ten years, I have managed the Residential Mortgage Backed Securities (RMBS) litigation on behalf of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and various Federal Home Loan banks. Before that, I handled discovery management in the Bernie Madoff bankruptcy litigation. Outside the office, I serve on the Board of Directors of Birch Family Services, Inc. and on its Audit and Compliance Committee. I also sit on the Advisory Boards of Higher Talent and The Merlin OpenSource Foundation. At Karta Legal, I have assembled an entire ecosystem to help organizations in their legal innovation journey. In my team, I have experts in change management, process improvement and mapping, legal technology and the use of AI, cybersecurity and privacy, data management and analytics, e-discovery, project management, and litigation support. We know what works, what doesn't, and how much it should cost.  My goal is innovation and re-designing the delivery of legal services. The path to innovation is simple. First, focus on the people. Second, design or redesign the process. Third, pick the right technology for your specific needs and your budget. To achieve those goals, I use a variety of design thinking and business process improvement tools selected from Lean Six Sigma and Agile Project Management methodologies. Over the years, I have curated and tailored these tools to fit the needs of the legal industry and have applied them successfully. When asked to describe myself I say I am part lawyer, process maven, technologist, educator, Lean Six Sigma facilitator, and innovation driver. Why should we change the way we deliver legal services? The most fundamental reason is because we are bound by professional responsibilities and ethical duties to become technology competent and provide speedy and efficient representation. The most practical reason is because it makes good business sense.
Title: CEO Karta Legal | Chief Change Instigator | Innovation Driver | JD | Lean Six Sigma Black Belt | Lean Six Sigma Sensei

Summary: Tomi is currently Chief Drug Hunter and President, Maestro Therapeutics, a consulting/advisory enterprise that is engaging academia, biotech and pharma to support peptide drug discovery. He is well known for his contributions to GPCR, kinase, protease and protein-protein interaction drug discovery. He has two marketed drugs, including Scenesse¬Æ (a peptide superagonist of MCR1 for the treatment of the orphan skin disease known as erythropoietic protophyria and related indications) and Iclusig¬Æ (a small-molecule inhibitor of Bcr-Abl kinase for the treatment of resistant forms of chronic myelogenous leukemia). Other examples of his drug development campaigns include the peptidomimetic renin inhibitor Ditekiren, a natural product macrocycle mTOR antagonist Ridaforolimus and the first stapled peptide dual MDM2‚ÄìMDMX antagonist ALRN-6924. Tomi is credited with ~600 scientific publications, patents, and presentations and holds several Adjunct Professorships at the University of Massachusetts, the University of Massachusetts Medical School and Northeastern University Center for Drug Discovery. He is a Distinguished Alumni Scholar from his undergraduate alma mater, Minnesota State University at Moorhead, and served as a member of the MSUM Alumni Foundation Board of Directors. Summary: BREAK THROUGH THE CEILING AND SCALE YOUR BUSINESS As CEO, are you stuck in the weeds... constantly pulled into the day-to-day operation? Of course you intend to help, but just like a parent solving their children's biggest challenges, you're creating a dependency on you. For your people to solve their problems so they don't keep coming back again and again, they need to shift from firefighting and surface level solutions, instead, to root-level problem solving. Solving problems at the root means that those problems go away forever. Here are some tools that will help you strengthen your roots: Hold a weekly meeting, first for your leadership team, and eventually for every group in your company. The meeting exists for one reason: to SURFACE and SOLVE your company's biggest challenges at the root level.  Discover the single metric - and it will be different for everyone - that captures each person's most important value contribution to your company. Then, have each person track, weekly, the target and actual value of that metric.  Help each of your leaders define their 3 most important quarterly goals. Then, review whether those goals are on course at your weekly leadership meeting.  As coaches, we work closely with your leadership team to systematize your business. This means everyone in your company has the same processes, tools, vocabulary and vision. From this, strong accountability, alignment and execution emerge.  Just like a nutritionist can help you with physical health and a psychologist can help with mental health, we help your company achieve organizational health. This enables you to do less of what you shouldn't be doing, and more of what you love! If you're looking to scale up, I invite you to have a conversation. Whether or not we work together, I'm confident our call will be full of insights and actionable steps that can help you grow your business.  Schedule a call: https://calendly.com/klenoff/10-minute-strategy-call Email me: josh@helm.ceo.
